awd_titl_txt: 1D and 2D Cross-Linking of Patterned Monolayers: From Molecules to Reactive Templates
awd_abstract_narration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Matthew Zimmt in the Department of Chemistry at Brown University.  Professor Zimmt is developing methods to prepare patterned molecular films. Each patterned sheet is used as a high-resolution template to assemble objects, polymers, and biological molecules into a patterned array. This process generates fields of molecules regularly distributed across a surface. The potential uses of these surfaces include converting solar energy into electricity. Research students involved in this project receive broad training in interdisciplinary science. The public is engaged through the production and circulation of animated videos that introduce self-assembly and its relevance to modern life. Undergraduate art majors and science majors, the Brown Science Center, and Brown faculty collaborate to produce these videos, which are distributed through various platforms.

Professor Zimmt is investigating strategies for preparing patterned, multi-component, self-assembled monolayers with unit cell repeats extending to 40 nanometers (nm), and with spatially patterned chemical reactivity on a less than 10 nanometer length scale.  Methods to cross-link and stabilize these films are developed.  In order to study these films, laser desorption-ionization, time-of-flight mass spectrometry is developed as a tool to investigate the assembly, composition, and reactions of physisorbed self-assembled monolayers on graphite and other conductive surfaces. Professor Zimmt integrates the research outcomes into the education of undergraduate and graduate students at Brown University.  Through collaboration with the Brown Science Center, the project team produces an animated video introducing self-assembly and its relevance to daily life. This self-assembly video is being distributed online and through other media platforms.

por.por_cntn:
Interactions between molecules determine the structures and physical properties of the materials we encounter every day. Attractive interactions are generated by opposite charges (Coulomb, dipolar and hydrogen bonding interactions) and by molecular polarizability (van der Waals attractions). Repulsive interactions are generated by identical charges (Coulomb, dipolar repulsions) and by extremely small distances between atoms (van der Waals repulsions). The balance of these interactions determines whether collections of molecules assemble as a gas, liquid or solid. The presence of a surface (or an interface) can constrain the orientations and shapes that molecules access, thus promoting assembly of new structures. Spontaneous assembly of molecules at surfaces (self-assembly) provides insights into fundamental interactions of molecules but is also a tool to produce one-molecule thick materials (monolayers) that cannot be accessed by other methods.   

By proper design and selection of molecular structures, self-assembly on planar surfaces reproducibly forms highly complex patterns of molecules that extend across the surface with a regularly repeating structural unit. One outcome of this research project has been application of bis-diyne aliphatic chains whose programmable, shape-based interactions direct self-assembly of compositionally patterned monolayers with high fidelity. Programmable assembly of molecular patterns on surfaces has potential as a strategy to template construction of novel 3-D materials from a surface. Research supported by this grant demonstrated self-assembly of a designed, patterned layer of gold nanoparticles directed by disulfide functional group placement in an underlying, two-component patterned monolayer that was self-assembled on a graphite surface. Templating of the gold nanoparticle layer involved patterned monolayer assembly followed by linking adjacent pairs of molecules with a disulfide group that subsequently captured gold nanoparticles from solution. Linking adjacent molecules after monolayer self-assembly was essential; self-assembly of compositionally patterned monolayers requires exchange of molecular components between monolayer and solution to access the lowest free energy (equilibrated) monolayer structure. The need for exchange during self-assembly limits the durability and the post-assembly treatments that patterned molecular monolayers can survive. This project demonstrated that linking pairs of molecules (dimer formation) after monolayer self-assembly locked-in the pattern formed by self-assembly, was adequate to inhibit molecular exchange into solution and to allow dimers to anchor nanoparticles to the surface.

The development of facile methods to convert physisorbed patterned molecular monolayers into more robust, polymerized monolayers (dimers being the first step of polymer formation) would allow broader application of patterned monolayers for self-assembly and material science applications. Research supported by this grant demonstrated two methods for polymerizing molecular monolayers in ways that do not alter the molecular structure in contact with the underlying surface. The first is a reversible method of monolayer polymerization based on redox interconversion of thiols and disufide functional groups. The second is an irreversible method of monolayer polymerization based on Glaser-Hay coupling of pendant alkyne chains. Both methods install functional groups that can be used as chemical anchors in a template to self-assemble a second layer on the patterned monolayer. The kinetics of Glaser-Hay coupling and the durability of the polymerized monolayers were characterized using novel applications of laser desorption / ionization mass spectrometry.

Combining appropriate literature approaches for self-assembly of patterned molecular monolayers with outcomes arising from this project, including bis-diyne chains, off-surface polymerization strategies, strategies for second layer construction and analytical methods (LDI-TOF, MALDI-TOF and MALDI-FTICR mass spectrometry of monolayers) provides novel capabilities to self-assembly researchers and material scientists working to develop and utilize patterned (monolayers on) surfaces.
